results.title: [The White continent]
results.brief_description:
Please be advised, this film contains graphic footage of animal cruelty.

In late 1949, a joint expedition planned by the Governments of Britain, Norway and Sweden left for Queen Maude Land on the Antarctic continent - this was to be the first truly international expedition to the Antarctic. The film covers the first stage of the journey, from departure point in Europe to the establishment of the base camps and later withdrawal of the ship’s party, leaving the groups of scientists to their study of the unknown world of ice and snow. Photography by Tom Stobart.

results.title: Weevils mean business
results.creator_credit: AWB Limited and Fraser Castle Productions
results.brief_description: The problem of weevil infestation in bulk wheat storage and its control in Australia. Weevils and other insect pests in grain are a potential danger to the well-being of Australian wheatgrowers. Shows the Board’s suggested methods of insect control on the farm and traces the story of Australian wheat from the farm to its consumption overseas.

results.title: Waterfront safety
results.creator_credit: Western Australia. Dept. of Labour and Western Australian Government Film Unit
results.brief_description:
This 1966 film takes place on the wharfs and ships at Fremantle Harbour, demonstrating safe working methods for waterside workers. It shows the correct handling of various types of cargo, including logs, grain and phosphate mined from Nauru. It emphasises the use of protective clothing and equipment. The film also shows the prevention and control of fires, including fire fighting ships.

Produced by the Western Australian Government Film Unit and presented by the Western Australian Department of Labour with Accident Prevention Organisation (Shipping).

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Water against wildfire
results.creator_credit: David Morgan, John Richardson, Kestrel Films (Australia) and Victorian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: This film was made at the request of Victoria’s Forest Commission. Bush fires all over Australia and indeed all parts of the world create havoc not only on the environment of humans but also on the delicate balance of the natural world. A training film directed towards forest workers on how to use water on forest fires and the follow-up after the fire has been contained.

results.title: The Vision of William Blake (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Guy Brenton, British Film Institute Experimental Film Fund and Morse Films
results.brief_description: Filmed in four museums that contain major collections of Blake’s writings and paintings, this documentary by Guy Brenton explores the anguish of Blake’s prophetic world, Music by Ralph Vaughan Williams, and narration and poems read by Bernard Miles and Robert Speight.

results.title: News digest [No. 9]
results.creator_credit: ABC and State Film Centre of Victoria
results.brief_description: Cinemagazine items: Kyabram’s rodeo; 12,000 sea shells collected from the world’s beaches; Victoria’s first mobile water patrol equipped with a bar tender cruiser is launched at Sandringham; underwater enthusiasts collect relics from old steamers; movies on the move at the Myer Music Bowl shown by the State Film Centre on a 24 by 8 foot screen as part of the Moomba festivities.

results.title: Viewpoint on Adelaide
results.creator_credit: Lilias Fraser, Don Murray and Film Australia
results.brief_description: The city of Adelaide, South Australia, as seen through the eyes of European migrants. Becoming accustomed to Australia was the main problem of migrants in this film. The language barrier, strange customs and the long hours of work required to become established are discussed.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lilias Fraser, Don Murray and Film Australia

results.title: Victoria: 100 years of progress
results.brief_description:
This documentary looks in detail at the history and development of Melbourne, using artist’s sketches and filmed footage to depict the history of Melbourne. Some items include the Manchester Unity Building, cars of the era travelling down St Kilda Road, St Kilda Beach, a brief history of the Princes Bridge, the Royal Botanic Gardens, Geelong and industries and transport existing in 1934. Also includes footage of the opening of Parliament.

Includes archival footage of early transport-cars; shipping; rail (Flinders Street Station); Prince’s Bridge; St. Kilda Beach; Anzac Parade; Flemington Race Course. Arrival of the Duke and Duchess of York for the first opening of Federal Parliament 1901. Also featured: scenes of the city: Collins and Swanston Streets; Melbourne Town Hill; The Exhibition Building; Parliament House and large private homes in the suburb of Toorak. Reference is made to agricultural and pastoral industries - wheat; wool production; fruit growing and tanning in Mildura. Three masted sailing vessels plus a farewell for the ocean liner Strathnaver. Finally, a re-enactment of gold mining/panning and heralding the first one hundredth birthday of the settlement of Melbourne
[SOURCE: NFSA Collection catalogue)
